p: However, observational evidence points toward land management inducing important effects on surface climate (Luyssaert et al., 2014). Individual modeling studies confirm that land management practices such as irrigation (Boucher, Myhre, & Myhre, 2004), crop harvest (e.g., Pugh et al., 2015), no‐till (Davin, Seneviratne, Ciais, Olioso, & Wang, 2014), grazing (Eastman, Coughenour, & Pielke, 2001), or forestry practices (Naudts et al., 2016) can notably alter biogeophysical properties and biogeochemical cycles in large regions of the world. A recent comparison study of several land surface models (LSMs) for certain land management practices revealed that emissions from land use may be consistently underestimated by earlier assessments accounting only for anthropogenic land‐cover conversions (Arneth et al., 2017), challenging our understanding of terrestrial carbon sources and sinks.
